;;为什么像唐纳德·特朗普和乔·拜登这样出生于 20 世纪 40 年代的美国人对美国权力有如此大的束缚，为什么他们如此紧紧地抓住它呢？为了回答这个问题，我们的;US;编辑采访了数十位出生在同一十年的杰出美国人。结果是一个新的;六部分播客系列;将于本周开始。它被称为“繁荣！炸毁美国政治的一代人”。

;

;他们大约与原子弹同时出生，在一个前苏联时代的国家长大。 - 在技术、军事和经济方面杰出。他们的童年时期潜伏着对相互毁灭的恐惧，但这种恐惧大部分被舒适的家庭生活所消除。人们在十几岁到二十多岁之间形成自己的政治观点。对于这个群体来说，那是 20 世纪 60 年代末，这十年的可能性因战争、暗杀和街头暴力而中断。第一集聚焦于 1968 年，美国极端党派之争的起源故事。

;;H;;历史、科学;和常识一致：即使是伟大的领导者也会变老。 1953年，温斯顿·丘吉尔第二次担任首相期间，晚饭后中风。历史学家安德鲁·罗伯茨（Andrew Roberts）写道：“似乎没有人对他含糊不清的言语和脚步不稳感到惊慌，而这正是以酗酒闻名的优势之一。”几周来，由于丘吉尔无法执政，他的女婿和私人秘书实际上管理着这个国家。他从未完全康复，但直到 1955 年 80 岁时才拒绝下台。未来的保守党首相哈罗德·麦克米伦 (Harold Macmillan) 在 1954 年写道。

;

;对于大多数人来说，认知能力下降是这是一场私人悲剧，给亲人留下了伤痕，但很少有人受伤。当它困扰政治领导人时，损害可能是灾难性的。 1933 年德国总统保罗·冯·兴登堡 (Paul von Hindenburg) 并不喜欢阿道夫·希特勒 (Adolf Hitler)，但为了打破政治僵局，让他担任总理。一些历史学家将这一史诗般的误判归咎于他已经 85 岁了，疲惫不堪，而且可能还患有阿尔茨海默病。

;;一些;;一些火灾;很难扑灭。这场辩论是在乔·拜登总统;6月27日的灾难性辩论表现;，他结结巴巴、半清晰的辩论，正在发展成为一场大火。几天来，只有媒体——尽管包括与总统关系最密切的专栏作家和评论员——呼吁他放弃他的;竞选连任;。但从 7 月 2 日起，总统在民主党内的支持率开始出现下滑。来自德克萨斯州的代表劳埃德·道格特(Lloyd Doggett)成为第一位呼吁他下台的现任民主党议员。第二天，另一个人劳尔·格里哈尔瓦也加入了他的行列。大捐助者里德·黑斯廷斯也表示，拜登应该为另一位候选人让路。博彩市场在辩论当天上午将总统退出竞选的可能性定为 20%，而在 7 月 3 日则将这一可能性提高至 60% 以上。

;

;其他大人物一直在暗示;类似观点;，或者至少拒绝原谅拜登老糊涂的口齿不清。罗德岛州参议员谢尔登·怀特豪斯 (Sheldon Whitehouse) 告诉当地一家电视台，“和很多人一样，我对这场辩论感到非常震惊。”南卡罗来纳州代表、拜登的亲密盟友吉姆·克莱伯恩表示，他仍然支持总统，但如果他退出竞选，他将支持副总统卡马拉·哈里斯接替他。也许最重要的是，前众议院议长南希·佩洛西 (Nancy Pelosi) 最初对拜登的健康状况表示不屑，但她似乎为怀疑者打开了大门，她告诉采访者，“我认为这是一个合理的问题，”这是一个插曲，还是一个条件？'”

;;M;;OST 八旬老人; 选择为了轻松的生活。乔·拜登总统正在展开一场耗资数十亿美元的艰苦竞选活动，以赢得继续工作到 86 岁的特权。到底是为了什么呢？在 2019 年的上一次竞选活动中，拜登表示他想拯救“国家的灵魂”——他的意思是剥夺唐纳德·特朗普的总统宝座。特朗普今年的报复性竞选促使拜登重拾旧调。我们的选举模型表明，总统获得连任的机会只有 30% 左右，尽管 6 月 27 日候选人之间的辩论可能会导致民意调查发生变化。拜登的第二次胜利将彻底击败他的宿敌。但这也将使总统在白宫的任期再延长四年。他会用它们做什么？

;

;总统们在制定第二任期议程时遇到困难是很常见的。例如，乔治·W·布什(George W. Bush)在将联邦医疗保健、退休和教育支出转向私营部门的计划上并没有取得多大进展。巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 的第二个任期（拜登作为副总统在前排发言）是与共和党国会进行的一系列无休止的财政斗争，最终以参议院甚至拒绝对奥巴马的总统候选人进行投票而蒙受耻辱。最高法院席位空缺。

;;我;;迟到; 2021英国皇家海军向微软和亚马逊网络服务这两家美国科技巨头提出了一个问题：是否有更好的方式来发动战争？更具体地说，他们能否找到一种更有效的方法来协调假设的加勒比海突击队和护卫舰的导弹系统？这些科技公司与大型军火制造商 BAE Systems 和规模较小的新贵 Anduril 等军事承包商进行了合作。在 12 周之内（在国防采购领域速度之快令人难以置信），该联盟聚集在英国萨默塞特，展示了名为 StormCloud 的产品。

;

;地面上的海军陆战队员、空中的无人机和许多其他传感器通过先进无线电的“网状”网络连接起来，使每个人都能无缝地看到其他地方发生的事情——这种设置已经允许海军陆战队运行在之前的演习中，围绕着更大的力量。他们收集的数据既在网络的“边缘”（通过弹力电缆绑在突击队车辆上的小型坚固计算机上）进行处理，又在遥远的云服务器上进行处理，数据通过卫星发送到那里。指挥和控制软件监视指定区域，决定哪些无人机应该飞到哪里，识别地面上的物体并建议使用哪种武器攻击哪个目标。

;保护整个美国的堕胎只能通过传统政治实现。 More politicians with liberal views on abortion would have to be elected to state legislatures, the House of Representatives, the Senate and the presidency—who could in turn change laws and appoint more liberal justices. Democrats heartily agree. They hope to harness the furious energy of the movement, and exploit the fact that more Americans trust Mr Biden than Mr Trump on abortion, making it a rare area of strength for him.

;

;So far, ballot initiatives seem to have boosted turnout among people who are more likely to vote for the Democrats. In Michigan, the abortion referendum in 2022 may help explain why 37% of young people came out to vote in that year's midterm elections, according to analysis from Tufts University. The national youth turnout was just 23%. In Kansas, which held a referendum in August 2022, women accounted for 62% of new voter registrations in the previous month, according to ;l;2, a data firm.

;

;A still more enticing prospect is that voters could be pulled away from the Republican camp. The midterm elections in 2022 hinted at that, too. Although only 14% of registered Republican voters were upset about the ;Dobbs ;ruling, a quarter of that group voted for a Democrat in their House district, according to analysis by Gary Jacobson at the University of California, San Diego 。 Researchers at the California Institute of Technology find a similar correlation: Republicans and independents who saw abortion as an important issue were more likely to vote for Democrats in 2022 than two years earlier. It is probably one reason a predicted “red wave” lifting Republican candidates failed to appear.

;

;Ruben Gallego, a Democrat who is running for an open Senate seat in Arizona, hopes to hitch his fortunes to the abortion-rights locomotive. He praises the ballot-initiative campaign often, and petitions circulate at his campaign events. In a ;tv; advert, he tells viewers that “We are at a crossroads” on abortion. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is trying to ensure that voters in battleground districts know about Republicans' efforts to ban abortion nationwide.

;

;In May a pro-Democratic group launched a $25m volley of ads in swing states, in which women accused Mr Trump of making their lives hell. Much more of that is to come. Between January and March 2022, less than 1% of Democratic adverts mentioned abortion, according to AdImpact, a research firm. By October of that year almost 40% did, and the proportion has barely dropped. Since the midterms, the Democrats and their backers have spent $123m on such adverts—over five times as much as Republicans.

;

;Mr Biden's campaign has paid for television advertisements in Arizona and Florida. One featured a Marine veteran labelling Mr Trump “not tough” for taking away women's freedom. Others feature women's stories of being deprived of medically needed abortions, with the label “Donald Trump did this.” The campaign is now trying to persuade Americans that Mr Trump would sign a national abortion ban if he were re-elected. He has avoided being drawn on the issue, but a recent poll by Navigator Research, a progressive pollster, suggests that a majority of Americans believe he would sign.

;

;George Bush's narrow victory in the presidential election in 2004 was initially ascribed to the anti-gay-marriage referendums that were on the ballot in around a dozen states. Academics are still arguing about that (some say that the threat of terrorism was more important). But the ballot initiatives appear to have mobilised white evangelical Protestants, including in Ohio, the crucial swing state that year.

;

;“We're not talking about a massive tide of people turning out,” says David Campbell, a political scientist at the University of Notre Dame. If the abortion referendums mobilise voters, the effect will be felt at the margins. But turnout has been an important factor in recent presidential elections, and small advantages in swing states can be decisive. Mr Campbell points out that taking away a right can electrify voters, and ;Dobbs ;was unprecedented in withdrawing a constitutional right that Americans had relied on for so long.

;
;;
;

;Campaigners for the ballot initiatives mostly welcome the attention. But they are keen to separate the abortion-rights issue from partisan politics. “Our job is to make sure that we are getting our message out to as broad a coalition as we possibly can,” says Chris Love from the Arizona campaign. “I think that Democrats really need to make sure that they're doing their job and speaking to their base of voters, because our base of voters is different.”

;

;Over one in three signatures in Florida comes from a Republican or an independent. In the referendums held so far, the vote to protect abortion has been larger than the vote for the top Democratic candidate. The biggest gap was in Kentucky, where in the 2022 midterms 52.3% voted against restricting abortion whereas only 38.2% voted for the Democratic candidate for the Senate, Charles Booker. In Michigan the abortion proposal received 56.7% of the vote compared with 54.5% for Gretchen Whitmer, the governor.

;The movement's impact on the 2024 election might not be as big as Democrats hope. But in the long run, it could change America's abortion politics profoundly. Abortion access has long been backed by a strong majority, but until recently the support was largely passive. ;Dobbs ;changed that. It also threw the issue back to 50 individual states rather than to the nation as a whole, all but ensuring, for the foreseeable future, a patchwork system riddled with inequality and fraught legal and moral questions. The ballot movement is the majority's first effort to take back control.

;

;Eventually, unless public opinion changes or American democracy falters, the movement is likely成功。 It is hard for courts or legislatures to resist indefinitely the adoption of any policy favoured by 60% or more of the public. This is particularly true about questions of personal choice and liberty. From alcohol prohibition to same-sex marriage to marijuana decriminalisation, liberalising majorities have eventually overcome restrictions imposed by conservative lawmakers. The ballot movement has provided America's silent abortion-rights coalition with a voice and with momentum, although it may take years or decades to fully nationalise a legal right to choose.

Myaa, a bespectacled 18-year-old in a Minnie Mouse ;T;-shirt, needs no convincing (“Oooh, yes please”). ;;P;;RESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES; is a coveted job, at least among a certain type of power-crazed geriatric man. America's founders nearly made the office more exalted still. John Adams, the first vice-president, thought the president should be known as His Elective Majesty or His Mightiness. The Senate endorsed another form of address: His Highness, the President of the United States and Protector of their Liberties. But the House of Representatives rejected grand titles, and George Washington went along with it to dispel claims that he had monarchical ambitions. The accusations flew anyway, and have been repeated whenever one party dislikes what the president is up to, which is to say most of the time.

;;I;;N LATE APRIL;, for the 75th time in a row, America blocked a mundane motion at the World Trade Organisation to fill vacancies on the panel that is the final arbiter of disputes among the group's members. The relentless vetoes, obscure as they might sound, have in effect completely defanged the ;WTO; for almost five years. Members that are found to have violated its rules can simply appeal against the decision, to a panel that is not functioning for lack of personnel. While the appeals moulder, the transgressions go unpunished. Two years ago, at one of the ;WTO;'s biennial summits, members resolved to get the dispute-resolution mechanism up and running again by this year. At the latest summit, earlier this year, having failed to do so, they instead decided, without even a hint of irony, to “accelerate discussions”.

;
